Before the recoil update Rust was actually a fun, competetive game. The game took skill to master recoil, gamesense, basebuilding etc. Even tho Rust always had their problems/bugs and game changing updates like the (compound bow bp) it has been a great experience and a great game, but currently my well known Rust has changed...The changing recoil made the game (non competetive) and more (casual) which many gamers sees as a good and positive thing, but I bought Rust bc it was described as a hardcore survival game, not the one winning a fight by luck/no skill and bloom which the current update (recoil update) gave us. The recoil is easier and can be mastered 100x faster than before and new players can outskill old veterans by just playing a couple of weeks learning the recoil. Of course gamesense matters aswell but Rust have been especially known for its hard recoil. Maybe the update gave new players a chance winning fights but the time (old players) spent on the game does not matter anymore. What about my 2000 hours learning the ak-spray. Gone for nothing? Atleast give the community no bloom and keep the game competetive with easier recoil like now. Btw Im traumatized by animal attacks!

For a game that gets updates nearly every week this sure is a piece of buggy garbage. On macOS must force quit application every time to quit. Achievements only sometimes unlock (even on official servers). Walls and floors have a mind of their own. Zero tutorial and a mess of completely unintuitive commands and actions.

An example: you go to chop your first tree. What's with the big red X on the tree? You just gotta figure it out. Why does it move around? No idea. Is there a way to hit it better and have it jump around less? Who knows?

Nearly every mechanic in the game is flawed in this way. Yes, if you spend 10 hours playing and 3 hours reading reddit and watching YouTube videos "it makes sense," but that should not be necessary. Like, how am I supposed to divine that I cannot remove a wall unless I build a TC first? Was it written in the stars? Crystal ball? Sheep's entrails?

In short: yes, this is an addictive game, but it could be a hundred times more fun with a healthy dose of QoL changes (and bug fixes). For heaven's sake, someone should give the developers a kick in the behind. This is amateur hour.

look to begin with let me start by saying that rust isnt a bad game. Now, does that make it good, great, or maybe amazing? No. Rust is okay. Its a fun game when you play with friends and dont take it too seriously, but that isnt always the case. Some people play this game 24/7 and treat it like their lives depend on it. Now thats the case with most games, but it is especially true for rust. Now dont get me wrong sometimes of course you take a game serious let me give other moments in games as examples, you are losing in COD, matchpoint in ranked siege, final zone in apex/fortnite/warzone, but rust is different. Some people know how to have fun but others dont get how you could play Rust in an un-competitive way. I play Rust where i have fun but take it serious when i need to. But some people i play with they dont think its the right way to do it. And thats the only problem with Rust. People just dont know how to have fun. Rust is an okay game, but when you learn how to mess around and have fun in it it becomes a 100x times better.

There is a lot of negative talk about toxic players. Which granted there are a lot. But there are as equally amount of nice or anti toxic (they will hunt them down)  

The crafting and building takes a little bit of learning but once you get it. its pretty simple. Can be hard when your out looking for one resource (animals. or stones etc..) so set out for a few as to not get bored, but not lose track.

Playing with friends DOES indeed make it easier. but there are also servers with 2x-10x resources. Which is quite helpful if you plan to play alone. 

Combat is not to bad once you get the hang of it and are able to get some decent gear which does not take long. 

TIPS 

DO not set up camp near where you spawn or along the beach. Find a quite area. better if surround by trees to help cover it up. 

Not everyone is going to hurt you. Be friendly first. 
Dont Give up if u happen to get KOS (killed on sight) a few times as a new player. You are not losing much untill u get a base raided.

While not for the faint of heart, or those who can't take a little griefing every now and then, Rust offers a great deal of varying gameplay for a lot of different folks.  Very server-dependant, Rust can be an all-out pvp battle or a chill gather-and-build game.  Be prepared for losing everything at any time.  Rust is not a game where you should get attached to anything, but instead enjoy the learning experience.  Every time you log in your experience will be different, and there's a TON of aftermarket plug-ins supported that expand on gameplay and keep things interesting.

Rust is definitely a game where you need to keep trying when you start.  Don't give up, keep picking yourself back up, and you'll soon discover a deep and rewarding game with fantastic community and mod support.

I shall preface this review in stating a few things. First off I have never played this game on my own, so I can't truly tell you what this game is like without friends preloading into servers with you. Secondly, I have in no way fully explored the full potential of this game and I played it a bit ago, so my thoughts on this game will be different to what the game is like today. And thirdly this is my impression of the game, so take it with a pinch of salt...
With that being said this game is somewhat of a mixed bag for me personally, but overall a game I'd recommend for the fun I had with my friends in this game. So you start off in the world, naked, cold and afraid, and you try and survive in this vicious world in which sadistic people spear you for the measley rock in your hands. But luckily for me I had a team, and we'd build our own places and venture out to try and interact with the people out there. Most of the time we'd be met with violence, but it's the rare magical encounters that kept us going through the tedium of building a base (especially when you are constantly raided so have to rebuild all over again). 
I think this is why this is a game I'd recommend, because when you can serenade groups of people to your cause just by singing, or forge alliances to defeat a common enemy, this is where the game excels. And with modded servers with faster resource gathering you can easily build bases and have fun. So overall I'd recommend this, especially if you have friends with the game, 7/10

One of the better builder / survival games i've played in a longtime. I got this game for free during giveaway back in its early release stage, i played it, hated it and closed it. UNTIL NOW. Recently, i played it again, and boy, this game has come a long way. The overall graphical fidelity is wonderful and there's so much more to do and so many people to battle or bases to steal / build and epic sites / monuments to loot and compete for. Essentially Minecraft mixed with some sort of fallout and tarkov / squad based survival fps blend. The largest drawbacks to this game honestly are the overall community of toxic players, the INSANE LONG load times (especially first time loading or whatever... jesus, can be upwards of 15-20 minutes..luckily you only have to load once..), and the optimization could be more efficient. Playing solo can be very difficult and brutal when squads of players raid you or gang up on you, hours of time are to be put in, but can easily be lost. Outside these factors, most servers seem to run by a weekly/ monthly basis, which is great until you realize half of them arent even weekly like they say they are, they just slap the tag onto the server. Another solid complaint is definitely the "soft siding" mechanic, where placing a wall from certain angles can simply ruin your own base or make a weakpoint, and sometimes you cant undo the wall to even fix it, even as the builder. This can be frustrating for starting players. Also server pops die incredibly fast, one day will be 200+ next will be like 30 players dead asf, i dont understand the mindset of quitting so quickly. Outside these factors, this game is one of the best survival builder fps type blends i've ever played, one of the best games to play with friends period.

Michael "Mike" Ehrmantraut is a Marine Corps veteran, former Philadelphia police officer, and a calm and calculating career criminal. He worked for both Gustavo Fring and Saul Goodman as a private investigator, head of security, cleaner, fixer, and hitman. He has extensive knowledge of how to operate on both sides of the law without detection. As a former beat cop and true professional, Mike maintains an extensive, up-to-date knowledge of forensic evidence, surveillance equipment, and police procedure. Mike is also well trained and calm in all types of combat situations, once using science and long strategy to take down a large number of hostiles with ease.

Background
Mike was born sometime in 1940-1944. He remembers his father as leaving him a "cold-water flat and a stack of bills," implying he didn't have a very good childhood. ("Coushatta") It's implied that Mike served as a marine scout sniper in the Vietnam War ("Gloves Off"). It is possible he has a history in special operations or intelligence agencies, as he has extensive knowledge of surveillance equipment and is well trained in stealth tactics. He also mentions that he specializes in tracking individuals down, no matter where they are in the world. Mike had previously been married for 22 years. ("Wiedersehen")

For thirty years, Mike was employed at the Philadelphia Police Department as a beat cop, frequently having to deal with situations such as break-ins and domestic disputes. His career was mired in corruption, with his fellow officers pressuring him into accepting bribes and participate in protection rackets. When his son Matt joined the force, and faced similar peer pressure, Mike was forced to persuade his son to go along with the corruption. Unfortunately, Matt's partner Troy Hoffman and their sergeant, Jack Fensky, distrusted Matt and murdered him by staging a gangland shooting. Devastated by the loss of his son, Mike fell into alcoholism and depression until he decided to take action. He announced his retirement from the PPD, and staged another bout of binge drinking, during which he tricked Hoffman and Fensky into believing he had evidence on them. When the duo came after Mike, he allowed them to drive him to a deserted alleyway with the intent of staging his suicide. Brandishing a hidden pistol and throwing off the illusion of his drunken stupor, Mike gunned down Hoffman and Fensky, suffering a shoulder wound in the process. He departed for Albuquerque the following day, where he reestablished ties with his daughter-in-law Stacey, who had moved there several months earlier.

Many people are unhappy with some if the recent updates this game has released. I am not entirely against what they are saying. The game was definitely more fun before the recoil update, but this game is in no way a bad game. I feel the reason people disagree with this update is because they are not used to change. This change is what the game needed. Many new people are downloading this game from recent promotions through twitch. Therefore, the game needs a way to introduce new players and give them a fair advantage otherwise they will more than likely not continue playing the game. The consistent updates this game is releasing are necessary for the game to prosper. If you are considering getting this game I recommend it to you. I would recommend you quickly find a group to play with otherwise this game could get annoying very quickly. People that you may know or people that you may meet in this game will give you the confidence and drive to continue playing. Personally I met my group I play with now when I was at around 750 hours. Here we are almost 3000 hours in and we are still consistently playing games together. I would not trade the experiences and laughs these people have given me for anything. Every game has its negatives, but overall Rust is worth it.

I woke up on a beach naked, next to hundreds of little ♥♥♥♥♥ that ran in every direction to gather some basic ressources. Me, being the absolute unit that i am, instead of acting like all of those peasants, i directly went for the kill, killing the naked next to me with a rock. Having bashed a skull with that rock and tasting the blood of this poor indian men made me go into a killing spree. Breaking every bones in my opponent's body made me fell powerful. Then, the same indian guy i had killed came back to me and started to pierce holes through my body with his fashioned wooden spear. My body, not able to withstand anymore damage, crumpled to the floor, like a piece of garbage you'd throw on the ground. My ennemy, whils't taking all the ressources i had gathered by killing all of those naked innocents, said quite a bit of racial slurs whom made me scared of him. As we say in rust, a man who's not affraid of using the n word, is a man you should ask mercy from. And i did exactly that. I asked him to spare my nude, pierced body. He seemed to think about it for quite a wile and then, to my surprise, said yes in an aproximated english. A friendship than begun.

With this man, i killed many. With this man, i built the best houses known to humanity. With this man, i laughed and drank. After 4 months of playing together, just before a raid, i asked him to sit in a plastic chair that i'd found in a crate. He sat down, thinking that i'd give him an impressive speach about why our incoming battle was our most fierce and hard battle, but that we'd still win. Then, i pulled out a weapon that made him realise what was about to happen. With this weapon, in a single blow, i made his body crumple to the floor. I then told him to remember when we met for the first time, and, just as he was about to pleade with me, i ended his life with that same wooden spear that had pierced my body 4 months ago.

Never trust anyone in rust, even your closest friends.

I will be fast and clear with my review. I started playing Rust around summer 2017 with a friend. Simply one of the best survival games out there! Here are my pros and cons:

Pros:
- enormous player base
- beautiful graphics and smooth gameplay
- can play with friends
- weapons and clothing customization
- unique base building
- a lot of PVP action
- raiding enemy player bases
- different type of servers ( modded, vanilla, community, etc.)
- day and night cycle
- every month the game has a major update and all servers wipe
- large maps filled with monuments, caves, icebergs, ships, animals and more


Cons:
- you can get OFFLINE raided
- time consuming (especially if you want to play solo)
- weapon recoil requires dedication and practice (especially the AK)
- if you want to play solo get ready to be wrecked during your first 100 - 200 hours
- to craft items you need to find and learn blueprints (also time consuming af)
- you can get randomly kicked out of a server because of a TIMED OUT connection
- requires a decent gaming PC
- FPS optimization lacks in some zones of the map

I hope this review will help you!

I woke up on a beach naked, next to hundreds of little shits that ran in every direction to gather some basic ressources. Me, being the absolute unit that i am, instead of acting like all of those peasants, i directly went for the kill, killing the naked next to me with a rock. Having bashed a skull with that rock and tasting the blood of this poor indian men made me go into a killing spree. Breaking every bones in my opponent's body made me fell powerful. Then, the same indian guy i had killed came back to me and started to pierce holes through my body with his fashioned wooden spear. My body, not able to withstand anymore damage, crumpled to the floor, like a piece of garbage you'd throw on the ground. My ennemy, whils't taking all the ressources i had gathered by killing all of those naked innocents, said quite a bit of racial slurs whom made me scared of him. As we say in rust, a man who's not affraid of using the n word, is a man you should ask mercy from. And i did exactly that. I asked him to spare my nude, pierced body. He seemed to think about it for quite a wile and then, to my surprise, said yes in an aproximated english. A friendship than begun. 

With this man, i killed many. With this man, i built the best houses known to humanity. With this man, i laughed and drank. After 4 months of playing together, just before a raid, i asked him to sit in a plastic chair that i'd found in a crate. He sat down, thinking that i'd give him an impressive speach about why our incoming battle was our most fierce and hard battle, but that we'd still win. Then, i pulled out a weapon that made him realise what was about to happen. With this weapon, in a single blow, i made his body crumple to the floor. I then told him to remember when we met for the first time, and, just as he was about to pleade with me, i ended his life with that same wooden spear that had pierced my body 4 months ago.

Never trust anyone in rust, even your closest friends.

Unfortunately couldn't get it to run reasonably with a regular harddrive, so honestly can't recommend it.
The loading times easily went all the way to 20-30 minutes just to get onto a server and the game crashed upon tweaking graphics settings.
Having a permanent character that I truely disliked admittedly left a sour taste in my mouth as well and I know I would've felt like I'll always have it in my mind that I would've hoped to get something I actually dig. But ofcourse know that I could have never changed it. I know this is an opinion many people (who don't care about how their character looks) aggressively criticise and mock - that it's a "non-issue", but I can't try and pretend like it wasn't a factor for me. If there's a variable set of how characters can look, I've always loved customizing a character and said characters have always varied in race and gender too. But just being handed something you don't like shouldn't be an issue either. I don't know why it has been made one.
 
If the dev wanted persistent looks for the characters, I certainly would've appreciated a one time choice, not something just being pushed onto me.

Still, the majority of the cause was on the technical issues I faced of course, I wouldn't have refunded on that alone. Just saying that I likely would've had the motivation to keep on cracking down on how to improve my performance past the 2 hour mark if I at least had a "lucky roll" in a character I actually like. Weird that it's such a contentious matter that someone would hope for a character they like in a game. 

If I return in the future through a discount or once I get an SSD (and I get a new motherboard, as my still-surprisingly-good-but-dated motherboard doesn't support M2 NVMe SSD's), I'll ofcourse re-write the review.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The EAC (Their anticheat service), alongside their human support team, do quite literally nothing in terms of appeals from bans. They've permanently banned accounts off a simple mistake on their end, and proceeded to do nothing to reimburse the holder of the account. Not only that, but they also hit you with many automated messages until you tickle their ballsacks enough to get a human to talk to you, which will only repeat the phrases the fuckin robot said. I really tried to like Rust.  The graphics are nice, the game play is adequate and even the newbie servers seemed nice.

Until, I logged off.  I spent a few hours learning the game, building myself a little piece of paradise and as soon as I log off, something or someone kills me and takes everything.

I thought that maybe this was a one-off or a fluke, but for the next week, no matter what I built (wood, stone, steel), I would die and lose it all every single time I logged off.

It's like getting kicked in the nuts every single time you login.

What exactly is the point here?  This isn't fun, this would technically be described as torture.

I don't recommend this game to anyone who doesn't like starting from scratch every single time they login and knowing that they will never get anywhere by playing this game.

So this thing, I don't even want to call it a game at this point, is a product for a very specific group of people. If you're not in that specific group stay clear.
- Rust will do everything in it's power to control your life, spend a lot of it online, have a shift system with your teammates to watch your base and such. It wants you to build your life around it
- even then Rust will spit on all that effort with offline raid, when you have a real emergency
- other players will be assholes to you
- if you want to progress by an inch, prepare to grind for hours
- Rust will tempt you into becoming awful human, because it would save you so much work to offline raid that poor fellow
- whenever you don't like anything about Rust, there will be many cultists, that will jump on you telling it's because you are bad at it, and you should git good (look at comments on negative reviews)
- the above is not a sign of a toxic community per se, it's a sign of those traits being required to enjoy Rust
- to be competitive you need to play it for 6 hours a day minimum, and should do so in a tribe
- when you're not competitive, you will get stomped and possibly humiliated
- it's addictive - it's not a good trait for a game, despite how many use it as if it was nice to be addicted
- feels more like a job, than my job
If any of the above are not for you, stay clear. Stay far away and never look back. I'm dead serious here, unless you're okay with everything above, you should never touch Rust, as it very well might drag you in and then you will experience all of it.
If you are okay with all of the above, go for it, I'm happy you found your place. But please for the good of humanity, try to treat other players decently and with some dignity. Also remember - your family and friends are more important than virtual base.

I played rust during the pandemic lockdown and became absolutely obsessed with every aspect of the game. Granted that I've spent most of my time in PVE servers with Purge PVP and to be fair, I played on One server in particular, Chaotic Gaming, that became RP and Chill late last year. The server is well maintained and there are so many different things to do because Rust allows map customisations and custom plugins there allows you to do things like Submarine events, boss fights and limitless Roleplaying possibilities. 

BIG NOTE
PVP servers are intense and definitely not for everyone. Would recommend if it's your first time playing, please try a less populated server or a PVE server to get the mechanics down first, i must admit, PVP servers are fun once in awhile but absolutely torture as a new player.

More than that, in Rust, I found the love of my life. I met my girlfriend in Rust and until today we still enjoy this game together. We're going on one year this August 6th and we were doing long distance in the beginning of our relationship and Rust has helped tremendously bridge that gap.

It's Rust. A game released in 2018 and has had constant updates to this day. Every update or change is always an improvement. Almost 100% of Rust is PVP based. If you're looking for a relaxing survival game this is not for you. You'll wake up in the middle of the night with cold sweats wondering if your base has been raided or not. You'll start to think "Is 2 hours of sleep worth more than protecting what I've worked for for 13 hours?" It's more hardcore than any other FPS. Most first person shooters I've played have been "Run and Gun" but Rust puts you to the test when competing with over 100 other people. Wipe day is like a Black Friday Sale and everything is $1 in the Best Buy. What's crazy is PVP isn't even the only thing in this game. Base building is so fun. There are so many different bases and build strategies. Pixel gaps, wide gaps, peak downs, there's just so much you can do to build a cool base. The cost of becoming the best in a server is dedicating your entire life. You become addicted and the game turns into job. If you stop playing at any point to get some rest after playing for 48 hours straight, you can lose everything in 10 minutes. Everything you do in this game is a risk. Playing Rust is gambling. Of course, if spending your entire week grinding for a base isn't your thing, the modded servers do a great job with accomplishing everything you want in a day. 

Overall:
 - A group of friends are not required, but is highly advised
 - Graphics are great
 - Game is getting constant updates
 - PVP is fluid, fast, and versatile
 - Base Building is unique and fun
 - Replayability

The game is pretty fun if you are into multiplayer survival stuff. Better than the others in the genre I'd say. Gathering/crafting/surviving is pretty easy to deal with and the menus are easy to navigate. Big plus considering some games (No Mans Sky) have inventory management systems that make me want to punch the screen. Hunger/thirst are not a constant annoyance and are very easy to manage after the first 30 minutes of the game. 

The real trick to enjoying Rust is to find a server that fits your play style. If you are normal functioning human who has a job and things to do, you can find a server that does not allow offline raiding for example. Took me a while to realize that building a base and then getting raided when you log off for the day is not the only way you can play rust. While some people find that fun, I think I passed that phase of my life (on a computer game all day) a long time ago. More power to them, however, lots of people love that shit.

While this may not be a game to everyone's taste, as a new player, I've found it incredibly entertaining. The crafting is crisp and sensible, the weapons work and aim well with a bit of practice, and the larger goal--gather, craft, build, and kill everything--seems to be a satisfying loop.

A few notes:
- Don't trust anyone. Yes, they may be friendly and engage you in chat, give you free stuff, and help your end goals, but they'll probably turn on you, ruin your base, and take everything from you. Like Dark Souls-y games, once you learn that you will die and lose everything, it becomes a *lot* more fun. You can always rebuild, and will, but getting upset about it won't help your next base or your blood pressure.
- Starting out, search for 3 hemp plants, build a sleeping bag, and drop it in an area you want to live. This should be close to some bigger areas with resources, but off the beaten path so you don't attract undue attention.
- Build a tool cabinet as soon as you create a base. It keeps other players from building too close to you; I think it gives you ~50m if I recall.
- Upgrade your base to protect it as you gather resources--wood and stone, hopefully with a hatchet and pick-axe, respectively--but remember that your base requires those same resources to keep from breaking down. Want a metal door? Awesome. It's great against nighttime ne'er-do-wells who want to take everything from you; however, you'll need to keep a constant supply of metal shards in your tool cabinet to maintain it. Stick with stone at the start; it should serve you well and is easily available.
- Enjoy a wild community of diverse servers and game styles. The servers that ban PVP killing and have unlimited resources can be a bit boring at the, "Wait, so...there isn't much to do now with my awesome base since nobody is near me and I have all a fully-upgraded weapon tree", but they're a phenomenal place to learn the basics of how everything comes together.

2 łyżeczki cukru pudru lub kryształu
1 łyżka cukru wanilinowego
2 jaja
1/2 szklanki oleju roślinnego (np. słonecznikowego) lub roztopionego masła
1 i 1/3 szklanki mleka

PRZYGOTOWANIE
Mąkę wsypać do miski, dodać proszek do pieczenia, sól, cukier, cukier wanilinowy. Wszystko wymieszać a następnie dodać jajka, olej roślinny oraz mleko. Zmiksować mikserem na gładką masę, tylko do połączenia się składników. Ciasto można odstawić aby odpoczęło (na około 15 minut), ale nie jest to konieczne.
Rozgrzać gofrownicę. Gofry piec przez około 3 - 3,5 minuty lub przez czas podany w instrukcji gofrownicy. Nakładamy ciasto chochlą i wypukłą stroną łyżki rozprowadzamy ciasto dokładnie po całej powierzchni.
Gofry po upieczeniu odkładać na metalową kratkę. Posypać cukrem pudrem i polać syropem klonowym. Lub podawać z ulubionymi dodatkami

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

This is a game that unless experienced with a friend/relative to share in the pain then you will struggle to squeeze the fun from it! If you couldn't tell from the thousand hour player reviews below, this is not a game but a way of life. Normally over a hundred hours in any other title would result in a pretty reputable opinion and review of said game..not here! Here your cred is measured in many thousands of hours and for those souls that live and breathe this game I can only salute your commitment and wonder at your life choices....but back to this game...

It is a challenging, unforgiving game that will reward your quick survival instincts if you are not assaulted by a heavily armoured individual or group that are simply patrolling, got bored and decided to gun down your naked rear. In the early days of rust, playing alongside my younger brother who had sunk more hours in, we managed to get into a server that had recently been wiped. This meant everyone had to start from ground zero, naked and afraid with a rock as your only tool for survival. We quickly found a spot to start constructing our small shop and soon (I mean hours later!) we had our solid structure that couldn't be broken into easily. We had a glass front for customers to approach and we used proximity chat to communicate the cost of better tools for resources. This worked for a time, we put on friendly Russian accents for some reason and things were going good. We even put on a small concert at one point, I as the guitar player and my brother singing. We managed to gather a crowd of naked survivors who for a minute enjoyed our show before they began bludgeoning each other.....we made a trade with the survivors and they went on their merry way. However, our small stint as Russian shop owners was drawing to a close when a group of armoured individuals approached. A large clan with plenty of firepower and bombs, two things that make short work of any base in the game. They had heard tale of our shop and so approached our window.....where they began speaking in Russian......They quickly figured out we were merely putting on an accent and took this as a declaration of war......needless to say we quickly found ourselves where we began....naked and afraid. 

I would like to tell you that all your experiences will be like this, a tale of survival and an interesting journey with a dramatic conclusion. Alas, I would be lying to you. For the many hours I have spent in this game around 85% of them were starting, trying to gather some resources to begin a base and getting grief'd or killed on sight by people that find endless joy in killing unarmed naked survivors. The worst part is even if you manage to make it to a point where you have a solid base, many supplies, a furnace and all the equipment needed to start building your own weapons you won't be safe. This game demands you live in it, when your character rests you don't, if you log out and come back the next day you can find your base has been destroyed by a larger clan and you have been killed. How you will know this is starting naked on a beach as if the last day of grinding was a mere false memory. You were always naked....you were always afraid......you never will progress beyond this unless you join a large enough clan or you spend the rest of your days living for real in this world. 

......but I still think you should give this a go!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

So, 400+ hours in the game you'd think I'd like it. I mean I do, mechanically and such It's a very enjoyable game. The base building, the electricity, water/piping exists tho it's never really needed. It's fun. The problem is that the game is not "consistent" in a sense it feels like 2 games. 

In particular pvp. 50% of the time it feels like I'm fighting a fair fight, win or lose, what happens is understandable. Whether it's a lucky shot or a back and forth fight drawn out 10 minutes. The other 50% of the game feels like absolute cheating shit. After googling what's possible, and what's for sale for this game, and what "free trials" exist, there isn't a single doubt in my mind I've been the victim of someone using ESP or AIM hacks. Across multiple servers. 

If pvp is your focus and your fun, find it elsewhere.  You will no doubt enjoy some part of this game, but eventually you're gonna get hit with the bullshit back to back to back with no break in between to fight some  normal players, and you too will find yourself uninstalling writing a review to hopefully warn others.

Yes, because I enjoy others suffering as much as I have suffered myself.

P.S. GOOD GAME.

P.S.S If you like to get fucked consistantly, this is the game for you. Lube not included.

This review is based on a solely solo experience. 

I'm kind of an oldie and a bit unsociable nowadays so I don't have friends to play games with anymore, and admittedly a bit of a loser nowadays. But never mind that, I DO NOT recommend this game if you plan on being "Strictly solo" like me. 

If you're good at making friends online or you already have friends playing this game, I can imagine this game being one of the most fun games out there you can play. Which is why I wish I could recommend and not recommend it at the same time.

So, problem with being strictly solo. Now you may of come from a few videos of people on youtube playing solo and having an amazing time, but do not be fooled. This will not be your experience, these youtubers have been playing this game for years and have many 1000's upon hours of experience and on top of that are much better than other rust players with the same amount of hours as them. To believe you will do as well as these people is arrogant...you won't.

I've done "ok" in community solo servers because there's no official solo servers. The problem with these servers is the population seems to die out very quickly, it's fun on the first day of wipe, (wipe is when the server resets essentially) and then the server kind of dies....

The official servers...forget it. Maybe if you get on the server straight after a wipe, but if you join a few hours later most people have guns and you're roaming around with a rock with absolutely no chance in hell to make any progress short of being extremely lucky.

An annoying thing I find with the game is I just wanna get a crappy bow, just some projectile weapon where I'm not just a defenceless moving target. But it cost 50 cloth...now cloth is not hard to attain when you have guns, because you can recycle stuff and get loads, but when you just got a rock and other people have guns, you ain't gonna live to get anything to recycle let alone get to a recycler...so you have to rely on hemp plants, which I don't know why but I just rarely come across them, and you need 5 plants for 50 cloths....I honestly think to give an advantage to people with f all, they should make the bows like 10 cloth, dirt cheap, so that at least I can shoot crappy arrows back at people with guns...but no. 

 Another thing which I find with this game is, when am doing quite well in a solo server, and I got a decent base and a few guns.. nothing spectactular, I seem to have an existential crisis, like ok what do I do now? Pvp...raid get more guns...then what? It's like ok every game is essentially a waste of time to keep us occupied when we're bored but this game seems to really make me realise it...so even when I start to do well I'm thinking what's the point....but that's just an issue of mine to be fair.

Overall, I think 10 years ago my mates and I would have had a blast on this game, but now I have no mates and yeh...I Enjoyed solo servers kind of, normally got outplayed but I did alright, considering, for some reason this is the only game where people brag about having like 9k hours in a game, so obviously they owned me..but...now I'm not calling anyone a loser, but who the hell brags about that. That's like a year of your life. 

I'm not exaggerating either, you'll always see in the chat people saying how many 1000's of hours they got in this game and calling people with 3k hours "newby".

This is a very fun game if you keep one thing in mind: You're going to lose. I originally bought this game a while ago but didn't play it for very long because I didn't enjoy dying often. Around a year later (I think) I started up the game again with the idea that I would lose and learn from my mistakes. I genuinely enjoyed the experience and was barely disheartened when I got raided. Within 2 wipes I learned how to play the game much better and have enjoyed the process of grinding for resources to raid, raiding, and then screwing around with the new materials. I would only recommend this game if 1. you have played video games on the computer for many years, 2. you understand that losing is part of the learning process, and 3. you don't give up easily.

I am a 34 yo father. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 9 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I want to recommend this game. I really do. It's so much fun and I've never played anything like it; it just scratches this particular itch that games like Tarkov don't. But until such a time as the devs take some time to fix the optimization issues that it has had for years, I can't recommend it and I won't be playing it. I have a pretty badass machine; it runs everything on max settings really well, but this game runs like crap with everything turned down. I've spent tens of hours trying to optimize on the software side, and I could maybe upgrade my ram, but if these guys really think I'm gonna spend even more money on my rig when I far exceed their minimum specs, then they don't deserve me upping their player count. They don't deserve you, either; they keep adding skins --recently they added one with changed stats which is literally just pay to win-- but they won't go in and add a texture for venison. It has looked like chicken for years, which screams that they're lazy or greedy or both. Or maybe just plain incompetent. Maybe one day they'll fix these things and I'll come back, but in the meantime, I'll be spending my time (and money) elsewhere.

I am a 53 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, find him in-game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he teach me what to do in this survival game. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since I've gone out from home to work. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I'm an absolute noob in this game, never played anything similar before.
The description does not lie, everything wants you to die here. I drowned, starved / froze to death, collapsed from thirst, were multiple times eaten by bears and wolves or stabbed to death  by boars. I did fall from a cliff, eaten poisoned pickles, run into a field with cacti and bleeded out on the spot. I've fallen into spike traps above and underground, died from radiation several times. And these were just the passive killers - the other players are the real deal - they broke my skull with a rock, stabbed me, shot me with bows, crossbows, revolvers, guns.
The thing is, with all of the above possibilities to die, it is almost euphoric when you... don't. When you win a little battle, when you almost lose everything running back home but finally reach the door and make it. 
Ofc I'm at a really beginner stage of this game, still struggling to survive, trying to build a not-so-s*tty base etc., but so far I enjoy it.

I purchased these “Gummy Bears” thinking “Sounds like a nice purchase, 5 Lbs. of delicious candy for a decent price.. Can’t go wrong.” Unfortunately I had to learn the hard way.. IT CAN GO VERY WRONG!! First of all, I made the mistake of not reading the reviews before my purchase, and that was a mistake I will live with for the rest of my life due to the trauma I received after eating two handfuls of these. I was excited to try these first time and I will say this, they were surprisingly tasteful for being “Sugar Free” and I regretfully decided to try less than two handfuls within 5 minutes before I had to make a run to Walmart to purchase a few things that didn’t include a stockpile of toilet paper. Within 15 minutes of consuming these high powered laxatives, my stomach was making noises that I should have seen as a message from God warning me, “You should turn back around and go home.” I excused the funny feeling in my stomach, as I was on a mission to replace a Keurig machine that broke from Walmart. Yes I said it, “WALMART.” As I parked my car, I felt my stomach growing more agitated by the minute making gurgling noises that struck me as unusual but I proceeded into the store as I really wanted a new coffee machine..

GOD HELP ME.

I was literally in the middle of the store looking at small kitchen appliances before one loud gurgle after another and then I squeezed out a fart that began as a long squeak to a jet propulsion in a split-second that probably had some people in the store confuse the sound as a gunshot and probably had some of them ducking for cover. As my situation had just gone from a, on a 1-10 scale beginning with a 3, (I might need to use the bathroom at some point, I should make this trip quick.) to an instant 12 (I’m literally soiling myself in the middle of a Walmart with hand towels and shower towels as my only source of fabric to wipe my ass with) I said “F*** the Keurig” and I ditched my cart and went running all the way to the opposite end of the store to the bathroom while, what sounded and felt like, I had firecrackers exploding in my underwear, people were probably pointing at me while their kids are laughing and I finally made it to the bathroom to find one stall available..

The Hadicapped Stall.

Upon entering the bathroom stall while simultaneously crying and pulling my pants down I jumped on the toilet seat not realizing it was literally covered in urine and as I began opening the flood gates, releasing the evil that moments prior had begun rearranging my insides, I realized after the fact that there was no seat paper and I then I began holding on for dear life while begging God to kill me, sounding off gunshots out of my ass that most likely had people running out of the store..

Very brutal in difficulty, and at it's core can be something great. But the game it's held back by the people who play it. 

The game is fun, it extremely hard and it can be brutal. Dying with loot hurts, losing everything in a raid is worse. It's a not a bad thing if you're prepared for it. However, the players you encounter are unnecessarily cruel, and by far are the most toxic people I have ever seen in gaming. Not COD not even LOL compares to the hateful man children this game offers. Not to mention the game is extremely unfriendly to solo play and nearly unplayable for anyone who intends to play moderately let alone casually.

Player interaction is kill on sight. If you're hoping any kind of cooperation outside of groups or any kind diplomacy outside of the shit talking in global, this isn't your game. People will shoot first, they will kill you, don't expect to grey man or people gonna spare you for being a fresh spawn on the beach. If that sort of thing appeals to you, just be aware it's 100% of the time and you're not safe outside of a handful places in game. It gets tiring to be on guard all the time, even offline because you will get offline raided eventually.

When they do kill you, and you will die... a lot. Usually they will just quickly execute you and loot your body. Cold but impersonal, like it should be. But 1 out of 10 times, people will play games with you, teabag, and talk trash. People are vindictive and juvenile when they don't have a reason to.

The stress you go through doesn't stop once you leave the game, you're always wondering if someone picked your base to raid while you're offline. It's far too easy to raid in the game's current state some explosives is all is needed to blow down a door. Not much stopping people from walking in taking all your shit. The final straw for me that not only was I offlined, but the people killed me sleeping in my bag AND MOVED IN. I couldn't even try to salvage the hours and hours of work I lost because it was all theirs now, and had the gal to rub it in. 

And of course there is the racism. They monitor chat, but they can't monitor proximity chat and they don't do anything about the graffiti. No I am not talking about fragile snowflake racism either. I'm talking about swastikas and n words with the the hard R.  I've seen someone was discriminated against because their character was black, which is stupid since appearance is randomly generated and players don't have control over that becuase facepunch is dumb that way. There is a large overlap with people visit /pol/ and people who play Rust.

This is me playing somewhat hard, forget about achieving anything as a solo casual. You have to no life the game and even have an app to keep an eye on your base when you eventually have to get off. You can't "unplug" from rust until you either give up or your server gets wiped. 

TL;DR. You either no life or don't play at all, and it's not even worth is since the community is straight cancer.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you are looking for a review on this game you have come to the wrong place, but you are looking for a outstanding Swirl Spice Cake Recipe you have come to the right place.

Ingredients:

Makes one 8½"x4½" loaf

Streusel

1 cup coarsely chopped pecans
⅓ cup Savory-to-Sweet Coffee Spice Mix
6 Tbsp. (75 g) light brown sugar
3 Tbsp. (24 g) all-purpose flour
1 tsp. kosher salt
4 Tbsp. unsalted butter, melted
Cake and Assembly
Nonstick cooking oil spray or room-temperature unsalted butter (for pan)
2 cups (250 g) all-purpose flour
½ tsp. baking powder
¼ tsp. baking soda
½ tsp. kosher salt, plus more
1¼ cups (250 g) granulated sugar
¾ cup (1½ sticks) unsalted butter, room temperature
3 large eggs, room temperature
½ cup sour cream, room temperature
2 tsp. vanilla extract
¼ cup (28 g) powdered sugar
1 tsp. (or more) orange juice
Streusel
Step 1
Whisk pecans, spice mixture, brown sugar, flour, and salt in a small bowl to combine. Drizzle in butter and mix until clumps form. Set aside.

Cake and Assembly
Step 2
Preheat an oven to 325°F. Lightly coat an 8½x4½" loaf pan with nonstick spray. Line with parchment paper, leaving overhang on long sides. Press paper into pan, then turn over, so greased side is facing up. Whisk flour, baking soda, baking powder, and ½ tsp. salt in a medium bowl to combine.

Step 3
Beat sugar and butter in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment on medium-high speed, scraping down sides of bowl halfway through, until very light and fluffy, 6–8 minutes. Reduce speed to medium. With motor running, add eggs one at a time, beating to incorporate and scraping down sides of bowl after each addition. Reduce speed to low; add half of dry ingredients and mix just to combine. Add sour cream and vanilla and beat to combine. Add remaining dry ingredients and beat until incorporated.

Step 4
Scrape half of batter into prepared pan. Top with streusel (yes, it will look like a lot, but use all of it!), then scrape remaining batter over. Starting at a short side of the pan and working your way to the other short side, drag a butter knife back and forth from one long side to the other through batter to marble streusel; smooth surface.

Step 5
Bake cake until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean, 80–90 minutes. Transfer pan to a wire rack and let cake cool in pan 15 minutes. Run a small knife around edges of cake to loosen if needed, then, using parchment paper, lift out of pan onto rack. Peel away parchment. Let cake cool completely.

Step 6
Combine powdered sugar and a pinch of salt in a small bowl, then mix in orange juice, adding up to a teaspoonful more if needed, until you have a thick but pourable icing. Drizzle over cake and let sit until icing is set before serving, about 15 minutes.

Step 7
Do ahead: Cake can be baked 3 days ahead. Store airtight at room temperature.

Roaming around playing meme midis on the acoustic guitar when I run into a hopping group of pantless raiders and we end up hosting a concert in the courtyard of their recently devastated conquest, joined by nearby rock-wielding nakeds. The improvised moshpit only had a few casualties.

Started a farm where I grew obscene amounts of potatoes to give to passers-by, playing some anime medley on the piano when a guy blows my head off from behind - before coming back wracked with guilt and generous of spirit and scrap. We vibed for a while, played midis for eachother, then he headed off into the sunset for the promise of gore and glory.

Yes, the playerbase is... a lot. But you get what you give, most of the time. And it's got some visual charm, best experienced crawling on your knees mashing the belt slot button that has your bandages and praying for a bit of luck.

If the vanilla experience gets boring, the modding community is frothing with creative endeavor and oxide makes the game extremely moddable, if you're willing to code-dive. Sure there's all the OP server concepts, but there's also some really developed and balanced ones too - like My Nice Town or one where you live on a mars colony. I find the best approach to keep gameplay fresh is a Low-RP one - choose a gimmick and play it well, without necessarily forgetting the violence (it's the end of the world after all). Come to terms with losing, just take it as part of the story. Every wipe is a chapter of bananas bullshit waiting to be written, most likely in your tears.

This game is like politics and natural selection, one man lacks power to overwhelm others whereas a group is undefeatable, progressing too late ends up basically being kicked off the server for the wipe by others who looked at you funny or speaking in a different language / accent. This game can be fun, I do have fun, HOWEVER, IF YOU CALL OUR BASE PHONE AND SAY RED ROOSTER IS BETTER THAN KFC, MATE! YOU DON'T KNOW WHATS GOING TO HAPPEN. So yeah, outpost trapping is hilarious and gets me one step closer to hell... sorry Abyss, I wanted your AR...

I am a 31 yo single mother, probably one of the oldest females playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 16 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his baby daddy's brother, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 60 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my little boy, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my boyfriend had left me. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Since the changes made from the recoil patch, the game just hasn't hit the same. Not complaining that it should be reverted, just saying this has become like Doom Eternal's TAG 2.0 update. You can check out what I mean in this video here that talks about Doom Eternal TAG 2.0: https://youtu.be/JC3hLlhyhZ0

Currently the game has the same problem that the TAG 2,0 has, where the game has gotten too easy, especially for a survival game. The recoil update did solve a lot of problems in combat, but it also introduced a lot of new issues, one that I would say was unnecessary. The biggest issue I have with the game as of now is the new gun sounds. They just don't work nor do they have the same punch to it as the original sounds had. Its difficult to know how far someone is and most of the guns sound the same, even after they tweaked the sounds in the last two patches to sound distinct. I had no issue telling what or where someone was shooting. Its just frustrating to hear a shot being made over a hill and to go up that hill to see no one in sight. I've noticed that I stopped playing all together after the updates and I have put in about 70 hours since the changes. I've mostly played vanilla after the recoil change, before the changes I've stuck to battlefield servers where its just a giant PvP arena since I didn't have time to play. Facepunch, please just revert the sounds, they just don't fit the game, or at least have the option to switch back to the old sounds. At least then, you would please both sides without having to choose what people want to hear.

Anyways, lets talk about the recoil changes. As I said earlier, it does address some of the issues it had before by not curing the issues, but remedy them. With the recoil changes, it did level the playing field by making the recoil patterns easier to learn, but it also loses a lot of the skill ceiling. You can probably get all the recoils down in about an hour, before it took a couple hundred hours to get all the guns. Sure it was quite the investment, but all the other aspects of Rust take a long time to master as well, such as building, which could take hundreds of hours to learn and master all the tricks to it. One of the biggest issues that got remedied was how snipers felt useless. Personally thought they were okay as it was more for newer players to use for long range pvp before they got good with automatic weapon spray patterns. Snipers are still being used mainly to roof camp and there were weapons such as the LR300, Thompson and the m249 they could use to PvP with. Those weapons were designed to fill in the skill gap for newer players (well the m249 being easy to spray is more because its a hard weapon to obtain for solos or small groups, but still). Currently, you don't have many long range fights as you use to so I would say in my experience, it becomes more sniper focus.
I've also noticed a big inconsistency to weapon damage. Normally you would get 5-6 body shots before dying from an AK, but now it ranges from 3-8 for whatever reason (no headshot damage either). That might also be a reason to why PvP just doesn't feel good right now. Damage is all over the place and its as if the game doesn't calculate the damage properly anymore.

Performance in the game has changed a lot and the recent updates have really and I mean really destroyed performance. Sure, they say that performance is fixed, but there's no reason for my fps to be 180fps two patches go, to 17fps last patch, and now in this patch I'm not even cracking past 117 fps. All they did was change recoil and add trains, how did I just lose out one third of my performance for no reason. I invested into a 5800x3D for this game alone (and at the very least enjoyed that performance for a few months), which got its shins broken. I've heard complaints in the past on the subreddit about the random performance hits and after 4 years, I've finally experienced it myself.

I suppose the highest point in the game for me was the patch in where they added the combat knife. There were reliable ways to build large compounds, turrets didn't need electricity and things were pretty alright. You could reliably setup a good offline defense even in small bases with a few turrets. If you plan on offlining someone, you shouldn't have an easy time, but there's also the aspect for onlining. If we're all being honest, onlines are rare unless you're in a clan, so it doesn't really have a place in this discussion. Anyways, then they added all sorts of visual handicaps, like Sun glare (why was this added?) and visuals when you're either too hot or cold. Then there was the stealth nerf to food/water. Food was and still important when I started the game. Around the time they added horses, they stealth nerfed food and water with no developer notes on it. You would be able to walk around for quite some time with a full bars and a stack of 8 corn, Since that stealth change, you need half a stack (32 corn) to travel the same distance. Speaking of food, personally I was sad the growing system had to change, but I didn't mind as it adds a new layer to master (not very difficult either).

Let's touch on raiding, offlining now is a lot easier than before. You just need an ore tea and get some MLRS rockets. Before the MLRS and the new military base was added, raiding was pretty easy to do (since everyone only offlined raid). Didn't take much to raid small to medium size bases. Now with the new inclusion of MLRS, small to medium bases take nothing to raid and even large bases cant last longer than a day. I thought teas were perfectly fine, gave a risk/reward to farmers and helped those with less time on their hands to play Rust, but MLRS just destroyed raiding balance (not like there was much of a balance to begin with). Word of advice, don't play in maps with a Military base, your base will last longer.

There's also the changes done to building textures. I personally had no issues with how it looked before, but it was really a downgrade back in 2021. At least it was no where as bad as the sound changes/update.

Then there's the roaming NPCs. A while ago there was a bug where NPCs weren't spawning in by the roads. The game was lot more fun since farming scrap already had a lot of competition and challenges. There was no need for NPCs to be spawning on roads, but monuments, I was semi-okay with until you find out the NPCs roaming monuments were MP5 NPCs (the hardest hitting NPC). Just why. The fact that the Facepunch also added to a patch that made it so NPCs caused players to bleed after dealing damage just made it worse to farm roads for scrap.

The new semi-automatic changes do feel great. Semi-Automatic Rifles feel like the sweet spot, its a good cheap all rounder, however the M92 got nerfed. The M92 was already a bad weapon after they broke its kneecaps a few years back. Its a weapon that you needed to purchase for a large some of scrap as its the only way to obtain it (outside of airdrops and event crates). There was no reason to use the M92 before and even less reason now. Why make it hard to obtain if its just complete garbage now.

I felt the combat knife patch was where Rust had its highest point of enjoyment, in my opinion and experience. Of course others will have their own opinion to where Rust was the best, but I felt raiding, farming, and pvp was great. Unfortunately the current state of the game just doesn't appeal to me anymore. There's so much unneeded additions and changes that were perfectly fine beforehand (again, in my opinion). Even with the terrible visual additions and offline raiding buffs, I didn't quit the game because I was at least able to enjoy the game in PvP battlefield servers where those weren't a factor, but now I can't even enjoy the PvP aspect anymore due mostly to the sound downgrades.

Rust was a game I didn't quite love, but had a fun addition to. Rust just isn't worth playing anymore.

Should new players check it out? I'd say no.

This game saved my life.

I am 37.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

So this is a review for the type of Rust player I am. I get in the game try to build a base and just upgrade a bunch of stuff do a lot of farming and mind my own business. I will help someone out if I can. I don't kill anyone, I don't raid and I basically just stick to myself. I've played 12 hours the last two weeks after taking a couple years off playing this game. All this game is these days is just a bunch of sweaty door campers and people that have nothing better to do than kill someone with a rock, torch and a couple hundred rock/wood. I've tried probably 8-10 different servers and it's just the same old thing over and over again. I'm all for if I shoot at you then kill me or if I raid you take all my shit but I do none of that. I only have weapons for hunting and stuff like that. If you're new to this game or thinking about getting it for the first time be prepared to never get anything done, die constantly from people with no life ruining other peoples time and basically getting nowhere in the game. The people that kill nakeds and just fuck with people minding their own business have sincerely ruined this game for me. I don't mind getting the shit kicked out of me if I mess with someone else but just me walking around trying to farm and getting killed for no reason is why I can't recommend this game.

This game is actually way too fun. I love playing it with my friends and just building our base up just to raid other people's bases. The server wipes (weekly, biweekly, or monthly)  help to make sure no one stays on top for too long and there are so many server variations to make sure you have the best experience playing. The community can get pretty toxic but there always seems to be a general consensus that veteran players always want to assist new players.

Highly recommend everyone downloads this game and gives it a solid chance! Some of the most fun I've had with my friends.

The only negative review I've ever made on steam. I'm a big fan of survival games, and I also like pvp full loot, so I figured this would be a great match. The problem is as a solo player, you are just farming for the clans. They don't need your 1x2, but they will spend more resources than you will ever have just to wipe you off the map. They will shoot you with an AK, you have a rock. I honestly don't understand the point in that. Seems like 95% of the player base actively tries to get you to quit. Toxic, racist, cheaters, you name it. It's a real shame, because Facepunch made a good game here, but I guess as a reflection of the world itself, other people have ruined it. Of course, Facepunch caters to these folks, the whales spending money, the no life's with 10,000hrs. 

You have people on Youtube making it look like fun, but they are spending 18 hrs a day in the game. You are not going to have fun. If you are an older gamer with a job, who plays a few hours after work- this is not the game for you. If you are considering trying the game as a solo, don't. If you are a toxic person who wants to join a clan and prey on new players- well then sure, have at it hoss.

I built a research table, got an achievement that only 10% of the player base has. This is a very early step. Rust is losing at least 90% of the players who try out their game. It's not because they are salty or weak or whatever, they are people like me totally willing to start over a few times. But eventually you have to ask yourself, what's the point? Can't build, can't farm, can't make progress. Get good? Why though, when you are just going to be offline raided? There is no benefit to getting better at the game, no benefit to playing it at all really. Let the clans enjoy their virtual kingdoms, I'm moving on.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.
