I bought the game a week or two ago (June-July 2022) and I've played about 20 hours of Rust so far. This includes setting up my own server and playing with another friend. Note: I did not do any substantial play on official servers yet, mostly because I expected it to be a miserable experience due to not knowing how to play the game very well and getting killed constantly.

I played on maxed graphic settings on a 3700X / 32 GB RAM / 3060 Ti / 2TB NVMe SSD. My PC handles the game no problem at 144 FPS on 1080p on my 144 Hz gaming monitor.

Summary thoughts:
It feels really old. I looked it up and the game originally came out in 2013. Yeah, you can tell. The way the assets load in, the graphics, and quirkiness of the game overall just feel like an old game. Nearly all of my complaints are probably tied to the game being built on an old engine and that isn't something that the developers can easily fix and thus probably won't be fixed. And that's fine. I don't expect a developer to switch gaming engines 10 years later. I knew I was buying a game that has been around a long time.

Things that really stood out (Cons):
1. It takes a REALLY long time for the game to load in. I'm not talking about getting to the main menu. That happens pretty quick. I'm talking about loading into the world after connecting to a server. It takes forever. I never actually timed it on the client, but I'd guess 3-4 minutes. It feels like forever though. I can't think of a game I've played recently that has such long load times. I can't even imagine how painful this would be on a slower computer. 5-10 minute load times for slower PCs are probably not uncommon. Painfully long. Ark: Survival Evolved loads in a lot faster for me. I'd guess about 1/2 to 1/3 the load in times for Ark. I tried it both while running a stand alone server and not - and they were about the same time for me.

2. Server start times on my PC were around 5 minutes. Also really slow. Ark server boot times are also long, but Rust server boot times are longer by 1-2 minutes I'd guess.

3. The way assets load in is funky. Probably most people don't notice, but it stood out to me as weird and janky. Something that you would expect from a 2013 game, but not in 2022. Again this is the engine's fault.

4. Really strange collision boxes. There were times that I was trying to mine rocks or ore. It felt like I was right on top of it, would swing, and would miss. Probably happened to me about 10% of the time. Often even repositioning would not fix it. Often the only way to solve was to crouch. Just bad engine collisions which is problematic of an old engine.

5.  A lot of stuff is not intuitive.

5a. Like trying to figure out how to water plants was way harder than it should have been. Water tank / water bucket usage was very unintuitive and had to look it up outside of the game after getting very frustrated.

5b. I also found the armor and gearing system to not be intuitive. It isn't clear which piece goes where on the body and which ones are mutually exclusive with other pieces. TBH I still don't understand it, and it is very trial by error. It drives me a bit crazy to be honest. The progression isn't clear, or obvious - neither are the pros / cons. I blame this largely on UI organization but also the design here feels bad from a progression perspective.

5c. You can't move or pickup walls after 30-60 sec of placing them. You can't easily destroy them either. You have to manually destroy them. This is probably understandable from a game design perspective. However, I wasn't able to destroy a stone wall in my base and it wasn't clear to me why that was. Other games give you a clear indication as to why a weapon you are using is doing no damage, or they show you the damage. In Rust, it wasn't clear to me what was going on and why my tool / weapon was ineffective or nearly ineffective at damaging the wall. I nearly broke two weapons, only to discover they did no damage after equipping my hammer to check. Again, trial by error stuff - but newer games often provide more in-game info to make this more clear.

Pros:
1. Lots of skins, some of which look really cool.
2. The build UI looks nice and feels good and is quick. But also it doesn't match up from a styling / theming perspective. I was fine with this though as I mainly only cared about ease of use / functionality.
3. Requires a lot of in game knowledge and personal skill to be good. A lot of room and variance in player skill levels and knowledge and it really shows in game which is great
4. House building is done well here. Lots of variance from build styles which affect strategic options during raids. It is well done and adds a lot of interesting gameplay which other games lack.

Overall:
- I'd give this a cautious recommendation if you don't mind quirks and oddities of playing on a nearly 10 year old game engine - and want high skill / high in-game knowledge gameplay. This enables a lot of really fun pvp opportunities. I would not recommend for PvE as it is fairly minimal gameplay and lower PvE depth compared to Ark (which has a lot of PvE by comparison). Pick this up for the PvP high skill gameplay, but something that is less twitchy than fortnite / League - and includes some persistence aspects and progressions tactics / raiding tactics around housing build strategies.

Here is a lovely recipe for my world famous pumpkin pie.

Ingredients: 

Decrease Serving: 8 

Increase Serving Adjust:

Original recipe yields 8 servings

Ingredient Checklist:


1 (15 ounce) can pumpkin puree
1 (14 ounce) can EAGLE BRAND® Sweetened Condensed Milk
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
½ teaspoon ground ginger
½ teaspoon ground nutmeg
½ teaspoon salt 
1 (9 inch) unbaked pie crust

•
Directions/Instructions Checklist

Step 1
Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Step 2
Whisk pumpkin puree, condensed milk, eggs, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and salt together in a medium bowl until smooth. Pour into crust.

Step 3
Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes.

Step 4
Reduce oven temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) and continue baking until a knife inserted 1 inch from the crust comes out clean, 35 to 40 minutes.

Step 5
Let cool before serving.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Maps are too small - even if you look for the lowest population server you can find, there's still bases literally EVERYWHERE you look - totally not a "survivor" game feel when it's always overcrowded.  Also, the wipes are WAY too frequent for anyone who can't devote hours every day to playing one game.  Extremely frustrating to work for a month to learn half the blueprints and then it's all just flushed away - WTF, seriously? So lame.

The game has promise, IF, they could:  1) make the trees dense enough that you could actually hide your base, 2) make the map large enough that if you want to get away from people YOU CAN, and 3) reduce wipe frequency to 3 months or longer (at least on some servers, for those of us who aren't gaming 80 fuking hours a week).
Communication is the most important part of this game.

What can be said about Rust that hasn't already been said? Rust, in my opinion, is one of the best games ever made. It can be incredibly challenging, but easily one of the most rewarding games I have ever experienced. And this game is definitely an experience. Ranging from amazingly vast and calm landscapes to head pounding PVP action, from deep underground in the tunnels or take to the skies in a helicopter. Few things can replicate the feeling of your base being assaulted while you defend yourself, as in Rust. Win or Lose, I cannot help but feel a great sense of great pride and accomplishment in building a base or two and living through a wipe on a server.

I will be completely honest Rust is one of the most difficult games I've ever played. The game is not difficult because of the mechanics (which may I add are really good) It's because it has one of the most toxic and un-forgiving fanbases in the world. However, if you can get over the community's ever-growing toxicity then I believe this game is amazing and 100% worth your time. So far I have accumulated 30 hours of playtime solo, and 20 hours in a duo with my friend, and they were really fun once I got past the difficult beginnings. This game offers a lot to do especially if you are willing to put in some hours and grind. The combat is nice but complex; at first, It takes like an hour of running around with a bow to understand how it works, but to any dedicated gamer that is an hour well spent. Rust requires a healthy bit of dedication and grind, as well as needing some skill in order to protect yourself and progress; but if you are willing to put in some hours I think you can squeeze out a nice 100 hours before it all kinda gets stale. Understand that Rust is 50% mental and 50% skill, the players that have the most success when they first start are the people who don't cry and throw a fit because they lost shit; it’s the players who get up and keep trying to play and have fun. Trust me being in a good mental state is in my opinion the most crucial part of the game in order to enjoy it.

Thanks for reading, any awards given would be rly appreciated.

Rust is a beautiful survival game that has competitive aspects that make it shine in the dark gloom that is PvP survival games. The mechanics are simple to learn, but a master uses them even better. The fights are good and the PvP aspect is balanced and well-thought. The base-building is realistic and very strategic and has to be done effectively and quickly. This, unlike a lot of survival games, makes Rust fast-paced and feel exciting; you are trying to survive and it's not easy. Thank goodness I got this game from the Summer Sale, and I say to you my friend that you should as well!

Rust is a game that's hard to get into if you play official servers as a solo beginner. If you have a group, you'll fair better the bigger it is. I definitely recommend getting into youtube videos first about the game so some of the meta comes easier. If you try community/modded servers you might find it easier to get the basics down. 

I learned the best on a PvP training server and a 5x modded server so I could just think about techniques not the actual grinding of the game. Once you have that down, go for the official servers and become a Rust Chad.

Remember to upgrade all door frames and foundations or else your base is gone!

The problem with Rust is it rewards players with no life or responsibilities. It's not to say those good players don't get ahead, it's just that you are punished severely for having low-tech items. The teams that play the most the first days of wipe and secure T3 BPs quickly then go onto dominate and raid everybody else. The "Always-on" nature of the servers is half the problem. The game encourages you to spend all your time neurotically guarding your stuff, at all hours of the day. The game is ruined by zergs also. There are zero attempts to balance for players that don't have a large team. You will never meet more sociopathic 12-year-olds, racists, and assholes than you ever will playing this game. The game is built to encourage griefing. It's not a game that promotes mental well-being. Played 50+ hrs of it, and decided to walk away. Do yourself a favor and buy something else.

[h1] Old and PvP Don't Mix [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I love the survival aspects of the game, scrounging in dangerous areas for loot, building up my little base to store items, and equipping my character.  Traveling at night was also a lot of fun.  Never knew who or what I would run into.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

The PvP.  As someone who solo's these type of games, I was just at a disadvantage.  Stepping a short distance from my base I encountered four players killing me - over and over.  I respawn at another location, and even though I'm naked, I get killed by any player that passes by.  I get it, that's the point of the game.  But I'm old, and it's just not fun fighting against those who gang up on me, when my reflexes just aren't as sharp.

Also, the community is laughably childish.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

By the second day of a wipe, I was already being ganked over and over by groups using guns and in fully body armor.  I imagine my little stone building would be destroyed just a couple days later.  Decided to save myself the trouble and stop playing altogether.

I know it's a good game, but I am leaving a negative review for those who think they may enjoy it, but really won't.  I watched a ton of YouTube videos, which made it seem fun.  Unless you're willing to start the day of a wipe, play a ton, and find a group, it just becomes a frustrating experience.  That, or you're a masochist.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

Imagine you, as a very nice individual, decides to visit The Outpost for the first time, you notice that the game registers the Outpost as a safe zone. Things are clearly going well you talk to a very lovely Lumberjack who needs help finding a bottle. After finding the bottle he gives you another task, a pretty easy one at that, cutting 2.000 wood. The Lumberjack also happens to give you a hatchet. You start cutting down the trees eventually accumulating over 2,000 wood. Unfortunately you've drifted out of the safe zone and it has become dark. When suddenly a very, very mean boar attacks you. You try and fight back but you didn't come equipped with the right tools, you try swinging the hatchet but end up dying. You re-spawn looking for your stuff and notice that you can't find it, after deciding to go back home and wait out the dark, a BEAR living in the forest decides to kill you. Frustrated you decide to just cut down trees with your trusty rock only to THEN GET KILLED BY ANOTHER PLAYER WITH A CROSSBOW. You've had enough you uninstall the game only to comeback to it a week later. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone that thinks games are too easy.

So I've obviously put a pretty decent amount of time into this game, and I enjoyed it quite a lot, until the combat update. One of the things in this game that really kept bringing me back was that you can put so many hours into this game. The progression/grinding was always fun because it was mixed with pvp, and that was the great thing about the game, the pvp was extremely unique. The combat update completely destroyed this for me. With this update, you can master pretty much any gun in a few hours, and when you do, the guns aren't satisfying to shoot. This game doesn't have the right pvp aspects to make things like tactics or strategies very viable or interesting, meaning that when the one major thing that made the pvp fun and unique, the very difficult and interesting spray patterns, were removed, the pvp is very bland. Because of this, I believe that the change is good in the short term for the playerbase and the devs, but in the long term, will have negative effects for both parties, as you can no longer sink that much time into the game. Alas, I will probably still play this game, but I can't find myself playing this game for long spans of time anymore.

I personally have a problem with this game, I don't really like pvp. I feel that if everyone formed an alliance and worked together you'd all prosper. After all, 1+1 equals 2. But greed and the just desire to shoot other players makes, 1-1 = 0 ... I don't know how to explain it very well, I do know that if you just take from other people you're not adding to the economic growth of the server, therefore not contributing to the advancement of server society. 

There are creative maps, where you build things. However, other games can do this better. This game just feels like a "punch to the face" in a lack of better terms (looks at developer and publisher names). 

Overall Review: If you enjoy raging and frustrations, Buy this game. If you enjoy fps and league of legends, this game is for you.

BONUS REVIEW (response to comment): You can have the same amount of fun in 7 Days to Die, looking into a chest and finding something good.. But if you look at the youtube videos where people have the most fun, it's them doing funny things, looking for ways to play the game out of the normal. It's interesting to watch, people getting shot down by their own greed in a trap base.

But I'm a fan of striving through cooperation, thinking of Star Trek Voyager Episode "The Void" where they're thrust into a battle royale environment and have to survive and find a way to escape, which they needed to work together to do.

It also applies to things like the science facility, it's much more manageable with a party of people trying to survive with you, than constantly getting stabbed in the back. It feels to much like Star Trek's "Mirror Universe".

You can play this game for a very long time and find an extreme amount of fun. This game brought me some of the most fun I have had playing video games ever. Although personally I find myself drifting away from the game because of being burnt out and because of the updates I think are making the game less fun. What I found most fun about this game was finding a group of friends and experiencing the game and learning it together, mastering recoil and then giving the new players what the experienced players did to us when I first started. But the new updates just seem to decrease skill gap and make the game easier, sure this is good for new players for like the first hundred hours or so, but this decreased skill gap is just going to make big groups become harder to beat and solo play much harder. Even though I think the game is going downhill and drifting away from it, it still can be loads of fun to play for new players. Just the experience is a lot of fun from making friends to getting back stabbed by them. A piece of this game will definitely stay with me forever

I love survival games, and I like shooters. I hoped for some mash-up of counterstrike and valheim - gather resources, build a base, go shoot things. But the PVP in this is just too hardcore for me. You spawn naked, you get shot by some guy with an AK. You survive long enough to build a hatchet or a pick axe. You get shot by some guy with an AK. You finally craft a bow and some armor. You get shot by some guy with an AK. You survive long enough to scrape together enough resources for  your first base. You get shot buy some guy with an AK. You manage to build a simple base. You log back in, and you're dead. You got shot by some guy with an AK.

You finally find a good weapon in a crate and you get the drop on some poor sap who just spent the last 2 hours gathering resources. You're rich! You get shot by some guy with an AK.

You have a good 4 hours to play with a buddy and you finally get a solid base. You find some sweet weapons. You kill some poor sap and take all his crap. You log off. You log back in. Everything you collected is gone. You got shot by some guy with an AK.

Once I realized that all I'm doing is running around gathering resources and building bases for other people to steal, the fun pretty much died instantly. I'm over losing everything I have every time I log off, or usually 3 or 4 times in a row before I even decide to log off.

I'll stick to games with some PVP where I don't constantly lose every single thing I've had to grind to get. Starting over for the 50th time in 40 hours was my breaking point.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

For the price, this game is seriously lacking, save your money and buy something like 7 Days to Die instead.  The game spawns you on a beach with nothing but a torch and a rock, and within moments you are likely killed by wildlife, or other players.

The crafting menus is awkward, and unwieldy, and the building mechanics are needlessly - well, not exactly complex, but certainly protracted. Not that you will ever get this far on a PVP server - which is the way you will unlock acheivements as all the Offical servers are PVP.

There are a handful of Community servers that are PVE in which you may be able to learn the basics of the game, assuming that asshat PVPers are flaunting the PVE status to go around murdering newbies.

hackers, and cheaters are rife within this game, in the space of maybe a few hours I noted more than 20 players get banned for cheating (this is heralded in chat) ranging from a few to nigh 100 days. This is of course only those caught to be cheating, I am sure may more get away with it regularly.

I would suggest that unless you are a masochist, avoid purchase of this trash.

I have a love hate relationship with this game. Its one of if not, the most toxic game I've ever played. High risk, high reward type of game. You spawn in, get resources, build a base and either protect it or go and try to raid other people for their stuff. It's like minecraft factions but for beta males. Only thing this game has going for it is skins. Otherwise its a buggy, hacker filled, mess. This game will give you anger issues.

This game was not what I expected but also exactly what I expected.

I came into the game expecting toxicity, a bad community, etc. But that isn't where my bad review comes from.
The game's first impression to me was bad because it's a very demanding game, for one that come out in 2013. The game has had significant updates since then, but is nearly impossible to enjoy unless you play on the lowest possible GPU settings for a rather standard GPU type. 

Other than the poor optimization. The game suffers from a lack of character customization, unless you make another steam account to "randomize" a character. Very poor decision on the Dev's end. The lack of customization and the randomness of the player character model pushed me off of a game that honestly would be better with it than without. The game idea is fun, I got the game because the gameplay seemed really fun, and it can be.

I had to refund because lack of optimization and character customization. Maybe in the future I'll try Rust out again.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Игроки:
Игроки в Rust встречаются разные. Большинство, конечно, будут против Вас, но если Вам удастся найти друга по выживанию, то добывать, сражаться, выживать будет намного легче. Но доверие друга надо еще заслужить. Здесь, игрок едва завидев Вас, либо убежит, либо попытается атаковать. Иногда они сами идут к Вам на встречу и предлагают мир, после чего Вы можете вместе обустраиваться или же охотиться. Если вы новичок, то смотрите видео гайд. по Rust, ведь игроки более опытные даже Вам не помогут, у них своих дел по горло. Однако встречаются и хорошие люди, которые с радостью отдают Вам необходимое. Таких игроков очень мало, всего около 10 %, а ведь на одном сервере от 150 до 750 человек. Только одни игроки заставляют тебя играть в это игру, это шедевр!!!

I played this game for a few hours and then asked for a refund. It appears to be an excellent multiplayer game for those who enjoy being slaughtered as a newbie by existing players who likely were slaughtered many times before finally gained an upper hand or who perhaps were able to join a gang of others for mutual self-preservation. In that regard, the game is probably very much like what a post-apocalyptic world would really be like with immoral predators at every turn in an eat-or-be-eaten environment. It's principally for this reason that I rarely ever play multiplayer games with strangers. It really looked llike an excllent game with best-in-class missions, etc. but it is most definitely not for single player, casual city-building/architecting wannabes (like me).

Addicting game that will make you stay up all night building, pvping, farming and more.

Amazing game with constant updates and regular new content. This is a rabbit hole you can fall hundreds or thousands of hours into if you can handle the emotions. This game is one hundred percent: grab as many friends as you can, build a sand castle, knock over everyone else's sand castle, rinse and repeat. The player base is a petri dish of humanity, the best and the worst and its a glorious thing. Wipes are usually every week with blueprint wipes once a month. You would think it would get boring and it can if you stay to yourself just building little 2x2 shacks on the beach but if you get a little group together of even 2 or 3 friends every week is like a fresh start with endless potential and wipe day is one of the things you actually look forward to.

There's really just nothing to do. Feels like playing an incredibly slow burn battle royale with no payoff, where you take 20 hours to grind resources & find gear to then lose it while you're working, studying, or sleeping.

This game brings lots of fun and entertainment. Solo may be rough sometimes but you meet actually friendly people every now and then and it's wonderful. And the view? Amazing, the graphics are some of the best I've ever seen. The gameplay is smooth and the idea of the game is brilliant. If your looking for a nice relaxing game with a little bit of spice and action, this game is perfect. I will still continue to play this game.

I've spent more time staring at the main menu loading screen and the server loading screen combined. I literally have more hours poured into this game by staring at menus and other screens than actually playing the game.
I don't understand what it is, I've tried plenty of tutorials trying to get something to work. Making the graphics and other settings all the way low (even though I have a pretty good graphics processor and cpu and plenty of open storage), but nothing seems to cut the 45 minute - 3 hour wait time to even see what the game looks like.
Like all I've done is walk my naked body a few steps and get to a tree only for the game to refresh and set me back at the server loading screen. It's genuinely killed my mental for this game, or my day/night in general.

So, even though I had door campers my first time playing, I've thoroughly enjoyed it so far. I do wish it didn't lock you into a random gender based on your steam ID. Would like there to be more available looting abilities, ie breaking rundown vehicles apart, trash can looting, cash register looting, etc. Definitely a game I am going to keep playing. Crafting in of itself pretty decent, and depending on what server you choose, some resources are more abundant than others, I'm looking at you stone and animal spawn points.

the only real con I can see with this game, are the door camping. That's pretty much it.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Been playing this on and off throughout the years and this is my current opinion on the game.

~ System requirements ~
Even with most settings turned to low, this game makes my GTX 970 cry and it eats more RAM than Chrome with an unethical amount of tabs does. 

~ Performance ~
Even with the game on a fast M.2 SSD and a 5820k running at 4.2 GHz, loading the contents of a given large vanilla map is painstakingly long. We're talking 4-6 minutes. Like mentioned earlier, if you even want to consider running this game with moderate quality you need a pretty beefy computer.

~ Content ~
Base building is really fun. There's some really wacky stuff you can do like multi-TC and floor/wall stacking.

Big plus for all of the updates this game receives. There's so many cool things like modular cars, snowmobiles, submarines and so on.

There's tons of monuments to do but the current state of the scientist AI makes fighting them relatively boring. In short, they're fairly retarded. Take oil rig for example. As soon as one lays their eyes on you, you can just hide behind a box and they'll know exactly where you are no matter where you go, chase you down and you can just exploit this to immediately gun them down as they become visible before they barely get a chance of doing anything against you. The elites you can just tag them all and hop behind a tank. They'll all pile up strafing endlessly and two F1 grenades will kill them all.

~ PvP and raiding ~
Invalid projectiles is one of the most infuriating causes of a lost fight, and it happens VERY often. 

The new recoil change makes gun play more realistic as people who had sat for days practicing a spray pattern can no longer beam people with an MP5 from 150m or more. The MP5 among other weapons are not supposed to be long ranged weapons, that's what we have DMRs and snipers for.

Raiding isn't really in a good spot. Massive clan bases aside, if you even attempt to raid someone with honeycombing, there's a very high chance they're immediately going to:

a) Upgrade the core to armored, which they usually cannot sustain causing the base to begin decaying
b) Wall off and start despawning loot
c) Both a) and b)

~ Overall opinion ~
Due to the overall performance of the game, alongside AI issues and lame experiences attempting to raid player bases, I can't really recommend the game.

Rust is a game that expects an unreasonable amount of time from players, to farm, to craft, to build a base. After which what will most likely happen to you is a more experienced player or a larger group will kill you and erase all of that progress. Rust is a game designed from the ground up to be as tedious and frustrating as possible. For the most part, unless you are able to find a vehicle and not have it stolen immediately, the entire map will be a giant walking sim. 

To succeed in this game, you need to have an insane tolerance to frustration. In the sense that you need to have the will to continually waste days of time in order to have the amount of fun you can have immediately in many other games. 

I have played rust for over 500 hours over all of my steam accounts, and it has been a constant cycle of slowly gaining resources, losing it all, and deciding that i was not about to stay up another 4 hours to get it all back. Almost none of your standard FPS experience will carry over to rust. I can clear an entire floor of demons in seconds in DOOM Eternal, however in rust you're more likely to be standing still, aiming down sights, hoping the sun is not in your eyes, it's not too dark to shoot, and that the guy who is gunning you down from half a mile away doesn't have a friend to finish you off if you're lucky enough to kill the first. 

Overall, like real life, Rust is not a fair game. Which for many people like myself, is not what we want from an escape from reality.

Rust is the kind of game that will make you laugh, cry, and rage all in the span of a few minutes. It's a game that is constantly surprising, and always keeps you on your toes. There is no other game quite like it, and it's this uniqueness that makes Rust so special.It is a brutal, unforgiving game that takes no prisoners. It's a survival game that throws you in the deep end and doesn't let up until you either die or manage to eke out a victory. The game is tough but fair, and it's this balance that makes Rust so addictive. The game world is a hostile place, and you need to be prepared for anything if you want to survive. The best way to do this is to team up with other players, as the game is much easier when you have friends to watch your back. But be warned – even your allies can turn on you in Rust, and betrayal is commonplace. This is a game that will push you to your limits, and it's all the better for it.

This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

This game also needs a new take on moderation. We shouldn't have to worry so much about people being offensive as much as they are at being hackers. 

Offensive material is subjective, it gets people banned and excommunicated for no reason, it's used as a manipulation tactic to ruin someone else's weeks worth of work. It's an unnecessary  waste of time and resources trying to control other peoples speech, actions or behavior outside of hacking. They need to implement a filter setting for offensive/politically correct chat formats that people can choose for themselves in game instead of ruining someone else's game that they paid for, or for their patronage on servers they choose to support. 

They also need to address the fact that this isn't a game for sensitive people, if your sensitive go play Minecraft. This game is meant for adults, with adult content, literally spawning butt-naked on a beach with boobs, buttocks, vagina, and penis all hanging out. When the communists are finally gone, and they finally do away with their "communist standards." When they are ejected or quit cause of the incessant whining and prattle of butt-hurt cries from actual children. Then I'll play this game again, then I'll give it one more go.

PSA: I have 4000 more hours on other accounts, and I started playing in 2019. 
    This game still has the potential to be great, but it has lost the magic spark somewhere along the line. Gunplay is flipping a coin to see who wins, and guns don't have a well defined role in the gameplay and progression at all. 
    I think the downward trend I see is mainly caused by the framework of monthly content updates. The dev team is fantastic, and listens well, but the outline of outputting new content every single month fosters a dynamic of creating and adding things to the game that don't align with its existing features and themes. 
    Given the complex nature of gameplay in Rust, any updates will massively affect gameplay, and a month just isn't enough time to examine whether the impact an otherwise beneficial update will have on the game. At the same time, Rust is a game of change, and these monthly updates are without a doubt what has kept it alive over the years. As players and metas settle, the game loses its uniqueness, its unpredictability that made me and many others love it. 
    I think that Rust is a game too big for Facepunch. They are a fantastic team, but the sheer magnitude and maintenance required guarantees that something will be missing each update. This isn't about player count, or codebase. It's about the infinitely complex nature of a game like Rust. Regular updates and new content are both instrumental to maintaining the most unique aspect of the game (its inherent chaos and unpredictability) AND harmful to the complex mechanics that make up the gameplay itself.
    Every content update, every item added, will affect different group sizes, player types, metas, and ideas separately. This is both the thing that has kept Rust alive, and the thing in my opinion killing it. It's impossible to strike that balance of constant change in the aspects listed above, while also ensuring it doesn't become unbalanced where a change of one type is overweighted. My final review, my summative statement is this: Rust is a fantastic game that you will inevitably grow to dislike.
This game is shit please dont buy it

This game is not for everyone. That includes me. The combat is some of the best you are going to get trust me. In a situation where you are one of the last ones alive going to any major monument and winning or losing what you've spent the last hour (if you are not in a group 6+) farming you are going to be attached to your equipment. While holding your emotion hostage makes for great game-play because your adrenaline going through the roof every time you are doing anything major it makes for a pretty bad experience overall. That is because everything else about this game is mediocre to bad. The community is toxic imagine black ops lobbies where any kid will bust out the hard r at anytime. The graphics are pretty realistic and good if you own a computer that cost more than 2000 dollars or else the game will run like crap. The game-play when you are not raiding (notice defending a raid isn't mentioned for later) or doing a major monuments is pretty boring. As it is mostly building your base or farming and hoping to sweet Jesus that you don't get polled up on by 3+ people because in most cases it means you are losing that thing you've just farmed for the last 20 minutes or so. Now it is time to mention getting raided. I've got to say I only experienced it once as it only has happen when I am on the game once because most of the people that play rust are sissies that have no life or are built different. Imagine this scenario you've done really well this wipe everything gone great. You've won almost every fight and you did your monuments and it went great better hope your friends don't have anything planned tomorrow because if they do you are getting offline raided (which means you are losing everything). I kid you not there have been at least 2 wipes (stopped caring eventually) where our group are all offline for like 2 hours and in between those hours we get offline raided. It's part of the game so learn to not get upset about it if you are into the game. Now to conclude the review. Throughout my review I have constantly mentioned time and that is important because the main reason why I don't recommend Rust is that Rust is not a game it's a job and a lifestyle unless you plan on doing nothing do not play this game or you are in for a bad time (as everyone is better than you).
Rock, Gun, Base, Gone, Die, Suffer, Depression, Wasted time, Repeat = Fun

I am a 41 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 11 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Such a great game, literally one of the best games ever, but as a solo you have two options: Suffer at the hands of zergs, clans, and teams, or spend hours grinding until you are a solo god. I have decided to spend hours grinding and it is making the game a better experience. Unless you want a game that will slowly suck away at your soul and make you question your will to live, don't play Rust. I wish I never heard about this game, cause once you start playing it no other game compares to the satisfaction you get from succeeding in this game. At the end of the day the devs did such a great job making this game but it does take its toll on you. I would only recommend this game to those you have a strong mental, or if you have hella friends who also want to grind hours and hours with you. I will not stop playing Rust but it has forever left its mark on me and my soul.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

The game itself isn't bad, in fact it's actually quite fun, but it's hard to recommend because the community is easily the most toxic I've ever experienced. The building mechanics are interesting, and even normal competition between players and groups can be pretty fun too. If you can find a couple friends to play with it might be worth it, if not, probably just play something else with a community that's less hostile. Kill or be killed is fine enough, and I could accept people killing you for resources, but the lengths many players go to inflict suffering on others, with no personal benefit makes me think the game is mostly a haven for sadists and psychopaths.

Loved the game for past 2-3 years but lately devs made a lot of questionable decisions ruining whole experience for me. I rly liked that Rust was like a Dark Souls of the PC Shooter world. Sadly for past year devs added to many monuments and made it 2 ez to progress. Even when I'm playing full pop officials the map is empty for half the time due to players being able to run low risk, low reward tasks all the time. The last straw for me was the recoil change witch killed the last bit of fun i had in this game. They justified the change saying that the new recoil will bring new players to the servers but frankly that couldn't be further from the truth. Whole player base is declining in a rapid pace and devs are focused only on making new sales instead of keeping their current player base. If U'll check the Steam reviews u can clearly see that most new players stoped playing the game due to cheaters and huge loading times but They'd rather ignore it and gave in to few reddit kids crying about recoil being 2 hard. I rly loved Rust and had a blast playing it but after latest updates I'm pretty sure that it will never get back to the state of the game that I've fallen in love with. Mark my words, they are trying to make another Battlefield/COD type of game just to please 12 yo kids playing in 20 man zergs.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This isn't really the game's fault, it just wasn't at all what I thought it was when I purchased. I was expecting it to be like other survival games (Ark, Conan,  the Forest, etc). First of all you don't even get to choose what your character looks like. That's a real deal breaker for me. 

Secondly, I thought the game would be set up to cater to both PvE and PvP. There really is no PvE or any sort of official servers where the players fight against NPCs. I have no problem with PvP, I just don't want it in my survival games.

Last of all the official servers wipe all the time.  I play survival games for world-building and base-building. I don't have the time or the type of personality to spend my energy on a base just to have it destroyed by other players or wiped by the admin every 2 weeks.

I was shot in the head within 2 minutes of logging in. That's fine as that is PvP. However I was repeatedly killed on the starter beach, naked over and over before I could even get the map out. Not for me man.

As a Noob in this game, it is very difficult to gain experience unless you like dying a LOT!  There isn't a single player option, they are all public servers.   If you have several friends to watch your back and allow you to develop, it is very possible to enjoy this game, but there are a lot of predators in this game who take great pleasure in taking out vulnerable players.   It is a very difficult thing to play for hours and to find you lost all of that investment in time . . . it is certainly not a game for everyone.
It does have a good research development tree to explore, and the survival aspects of the game are interesting, but it takes a bit to get the basics of the game down and to be proficient in the game. 
Generally, I would recommend to not waste your money on this game.  Fallout 76 is a superior game with a PVP option if that is your thing.

Great product, I bought this for my mother's new build house. I also bought a £10 signal tester. Downloaded an app which gave the direction of the transmitter (65k from Solihull) and started the install. Installed in the loft and it gave 2 green lights out of a possible 4, turned it towards the transmitter and I got 3 green lights (at home I have only 1 green light which gives a good signal). Finished the install and all done.
I was extremely sceptical about this product, based on the size of the unit and apparent ease... was also worried that I was asking a lot as 50ish miles from the transmitter was a big ask.
It did work straight out the box and in a loft. This saved hundreds of pounds in a pro install of an aeriel on the outside of the house. I tuned the TV and it found about 200 channels.
It does need power to work, I tapped a fuse spur in to a 6amp smoke alarm.

A common misconception about rust is that it is a pvp based game. This is in my opinion: entirely false. Before the so called "combat update" which pushed rust towards the first person shooter category rust could (and still can) pass as a simple open world survival game. Because of the "open world" and "sandbox" features of this game and with no story or path to follow this leaves the format of the game to the individual who plays it. And with the entirety of the content of the game being left to the player means that every part of this game is subjective to the desires and personality to whichever uncaged gorilla decided to log onto the server that wipe. In my opinion i believe that every combat aspect to this game is entirely optional and only there to open opportunities to the player the same way that there is farming tools or dive sites under the ocean. HOWEVER the one non-optional part of this game that sets it apart from EVERY OTHER BULLSH*T SURVIVAL GAME MEANT FOR DERANGED ALT WOMEN AND PYTHON CODERS (ark survival) is the spectacular community which has permissions to paint and say WHATEVER THEY WANT. My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

TLDR: Worth it.

After hearing a seemingly infinite amount of people explain how the game was terrible, I had to check it out for myself. After buying this game, I quickly began to realize that most of these people had never actually experienced Rust and were going off of the popular opinion that it is terrible. Rust is not the game for someone who has a busy schedule. I’ll say that straight off of the bat. If you work nearly every day or are a full-time student, this may not be the game for you. If you have many spare hours of free time, then it is worth it. The biggest factors that contribute to the hatred of this game are 1. The grind, 2. Community. I will start off by saying that the grind of this game can be very overwhelming and annoying. You can work for 20+ hours on a base, and one morning you wake up to realize it has been decimated by other players in the night. Boom. Start over again. It’s something that you have to be willing to accept when you play. Having the mindset of “I know that I WILL lose my stuff eventually, so it doesn't matter too much.” really helps the experience. The community is toxic. That is something that most likely every player will come to realize. There is no filter in the game. If you are not the one that can handle the bare minimum of swearing, this also isn’t the game for you. 

If you’re not “in it to win it”, the play of the game is still incredibly enjoyable. The graphics are great, though you may not have the best experience if your internet sucks. The sounds are really great, and realistic too (drinking noises caught me off guard). 

Overall: It is an amazing game if you are looking for a game that can make you feel every emotion within 5 minutes, that you can have a great time with, and is one that can give you a literally infinite amount of playtime to it. If you can find this game on sale, or If you have friends that are willing to play it with you, that would be for the better.

I have 7000 hours of 2 accounts and played since 2019. I went about learning the hard way for abour 1k hours as a solo and learning the ways of Rust the hard way, made and lost friends along the way. But since the new recoil patch, I am sorry to say. The game has lost its spark for me. What made the game hard and enjoying it was learning the patterns and actually being able to hand a far spray and how to manage fights with game sense you learn and you play. But the new update killed any SMG for any reliable range other than close/medium with terrible bloom (even with a laser its terrible), damage drop off has made any medium distance fight useless unless you hit a target 5+ times with the terrible bloom good luck. Ak is decent but still need a laser to be anything close to alright at far distances. The rest of the time I am watching people run away as I have to tap them to death hopefully then dont out heal the dmg or watch as bullet drop is even worse. I understand to change the meta and feel of rust a little but this update honestly has killed it for many veterans that I have spoken to and for the new players they will really never know the fun of learning a spray and dropping someone at 150m+ As of now I dont feel the game fun, it feels like a grub fest and chicken fights because unless you have an AK you will just hope to hit your target with the random bloom added + dmg drop off. All in all, new players goodluck but for the most of us who have had to the game and have to deal with this now..... Im done and will go to something else hoping Rust will change things back.

Don't let the bad reviews or toxicity deter you. ESPECIALLY the solo players. I solo most games and nearly refunded this one after my initial experience.  Then I found a noob friendly, solo/duo/trio server with a low pop, a supportive community, and some set rules that actually gave me a moment to get off the beach. The community is large enough and there's enough active servers to cater to any play style.

So play it how you wish.
Are you like me and need to jump into a solo or noob friendly server to get your bearing and learn the game?
Are you someone that prefers a chill experience and just wants to build? Well there's PVE servers too.
Or would you like to just dive into the toxic shit hole of the official servers and be murdered over and over by 12 year olds that seemingly know every profanity in the book? The choices are endless. And yet, all satisfying in their own way.

This game saved my life.

I am 69 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

“The Hog Rider card is unlocked from the Spell Valley (Arena 5). He is a very fast building-targeting, melee troop with moderately high hitpoints and damage. He appears just like his Clash of Clans counterpart; a man with brown eyebrows, a beard, a mohawk, and a golden body piercing in his left ear who is riding a hog. A Hog Rider card costs 4 Elixir to deploy.

Strategy

His fast move speed can boost forward mini tanks like an Ice Golem in a push. At the same time, he can also function as a tank for lower hitpoint troops such as Goblins as he still has a fair amount of health. Most cheap swarms complement the Hog Rider well, as they are nearly as fast as him and usually force more than one card out of the opponent's hand.

The Hog Rider struggles with swarms, as they can damage him down and defeat him quickly while obstructing his path. Barbarians in particular can fully counter him without very strict timing on the defender's part, though be wary of spells.

A Hunter can kill the Hog Rider in 2 hits if placed right on top of it. However, if you place something in front of the Hog Rider, the Hunter's splash will damage the Hog Rider and hit the card in front of it more.

The Hog Rider in conjunction with the Freeze can surprise the opponent and allow the Hog Rider to deal much more damage than anticipated, especially if the opponent's go-to counter is a swarm, or swarms are their only effective counter to him. Skeletons and Bats will immediately be defeated by the spell, while Spear Goblins, Goblins, and Minions will be at low enough health to be defeated by a follow up Zap or Giant Snowball.

However, this strategy isn't very effective against buildings as the Hog Rider will take a while to destroy the building, giving the opponent ample time to articulate another counter.

Against non-swarm troops, it can deal a lot of damage during the freeze time, but this can allow the opponent to set up a massive counterpush. For this reason, players should either only go for a Hog Rider + Freeze when they have other units backing it up from a counterattack, or if the match is about to end and they need to deal as much damage as possible.

It is not a good idea to send in a Hog Rider simply to destroy a building, especially if it is the only building targeting unit available, as defeating Crown Towers becomes substantially more difficult. Spells or simply waiting out the lifetime of the building are more effective. The exception to this is an Elixir Collector placed in front of the King's Tower. If a Hog Rider placed at the bridge, he can destroy the Collector for a positive Elixir trade, though the damage from both Princess Towers will usually mean he does not survive to deal any damage to them. However, if the opponent sends in defending troops, it can be an opportunity to gain spell damage value.

In a deck with several low-cost cards, it might be worth it to simply send the Hog Rider against one building. These decks shuffle their card rotation quick enough, that they will arrive to their next Hog Rider before the next building arrives in the opponent's card rotation.

Long-ranged troops like Musketeer and Flying Machine can snipe those buildings, preserving some of the Hog Rider's health, possibly allowing it to get some Tower damage.

When there are buildings placed in the middle to counter the Hog Rider, understanding the placement of the Hog Rider and the type of building placed can help the Hog Rider to bypass certain buildings.

Passive buildings such as spawners and Elixir Collector have a larger hitbox than defensive buildings; which means that if a passive building was placed 3 tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, then it is impossible for the Hog Rider to bypass that placement as the Hog Rider will get pulled to that building.

Defensive buildings have a smaller hitbox than a passive building, which means if that if a defensive building was placed three tiles away from the river in the middle of the opponent's side, a Hog Rider placed at the very left or right side of the Arena may be able to bypass it due to its smaller hitbox.

If the player has a building already placed down in the center of the arena, and the opponent tries to bypass it with a Hog Rider at the edge of the arena, they can use certain air troops to push the Hog Rider towards the building as it jumps over the river, effectively denying the bypass attempt. They must be already hovering over the correct placement, as very quick reflexes are required to correctly perform this technique.

For Bats, Skeleton Dragons, and Minion Horde, they should be placed right in front of the Hog Rider as soon as it is deployed.

For Minions, Skeleton Barrel, Mega Minion, Flying Machine, Electro Dragon, Baby Dragon, Inferno Dragon, Balloon, and Lava Hound, stagger the above placement one tile to the right if the Hog Rider is placed on the left side of the arena, and vice versa.

They can also use ground troops to achieve the same result. Something like an Ice Golem deployed at the Hog Rider’s landing spot will obstruct his path and force him to go around the unit, which causes him to be closer to the building instead of the Crown Tower.

The Hog Rider can kite Very Fast non-building targeting troops due to his own Very Fast speed and building only targeting if he is placed on the fourth tile from the bridge, slightly into the opposite lane. He can also stall grounded units when placed right at the bridge. He will pull them towards him while deploying, and then be untargetable by them when he jumps over the bridge. After landing, he will pull them back. This can be useful when the player needs to deal damage in the same lane they are defending. It will also help separate troops behind a tank in a large push.

A Tornado placed on the second tile front of the player's King's Tower and staggered two tiles towards the Princess Tower will activate it without any damage dealt to the Princess Tower, helping them in defending future pushes. This can also be a method of mitigating all damage dealt to a Princess Tower, but doing this more than three times may result in the King's Tower's health being low enough to be targeted directly, opening up the possible threat of a back door three crown. A better alternative is to pull the Hog away from the Princess Tower into the attacking range of all three Crown Towers, which will negate all damage as long as none of them are already distracted

A very powerful combo is the Hog Rider, the Musketeer, and the Valkyrie, typically referred to as the Trifecta. The Musketeer will defend against most troops, while the Valkyrie can protect her and the Hog Rider from swarms or high damage units. The Hog Rider is used to deal damage to the tower.

This can be effectively countered by Lightning, one-shotting the Musketeer and severely damaging both the Valkyrie and Hog Rider. The Minion Horde is also effective, but the enemy can Zap them and the Musketeer will one-shot them all. Even if the Musketeer is defeated, the Hog Rider and Valkyrie will have enough time to severely damage the Tower.

The Hog Rider should be placed behind the Valkyrie to give it a boost so that it stays in front of the Hog Rider, protecting it.

A Hog Rider combined with a Goblin Barrel can be awkward for the opponent to defend against. Timing it so that the Hog Rider is tanking the tower shots for the Goblins is the most effective way to deal damage. However, a Barbarian Barrel can shut this down with minimal Tower damage for a positive Elixir trade, as long as the Goblin Barrel was placed directly on the Tower.”

Various people are drawn to Rust for various reasons. Some come for PVP, some for farming, some just for socialising. A lot also come just to blurt racist obscenities and to be toxic to others. I, on the other hand, came for the ability to create, to build bases, to be an architect. It was back in 2018. and I still stick around. It's that good. Along the way I also learned to love roaming the ever-changing landscapes, it feels like hiking in nature. AI and unfriendly players add to the excitement of it. Devs work constantly on it, improving it incrementally bit by bit. So, if you're into anything aforementioned, it's a good game to spend money on. But a word of warning in the end, it can be highly addictive. See you on the beach.

One of my favorite games that I never play. It's so immersive that it consumes you, and then you inevitably lose everything and it makes you feel empty.

At times it can feel like all odds are stacked against you, because they are. While you reside in your humble stone 2x2, a nearby clan is constructing a new skyline to fill the once barren rust landscape. These gargantuan groups of people want nothing more than to have control, they play this game to assert dominance over other players, with no remorse for their actions. However, this seemingly unbeatable force will always have an Achilles heel, something to take advantage of. This possibility of success in such a dog-eat-dog world is what makes Rust such a rewarding experience. I would not recommend this game to anyone who is not ready for an immense challenge with no guaranteed success, or to people who are easily frustrated. Nevertheless, if you are up for the difficulty of not only surviving the already harsh conditions of the rust world, but also putting up with the even more intimidating threat of “other players,” give it a shot, you might have some fun…… or not.

Purchased this game back in 2017 when it was in alpha. I started off playing in a medium sized group for my first thousand hours and have mainly played solo ever since. I have always played on official vanilla servers.

I have not been able to find any better open world survival game that has managed to make playing with a few hundred random players on an island possible, let alone great. With Facepunch providing continuous monthly updates you shouldn't run out of stuff to do or look forward to.

However, this game is not for "soft" players unless you are in a clan.  You will have to grind a lot, You will die a lot, your base will get raided a lot, and you will want to quit a lot. Especially when you encounter a ZERG (Zero Empathy Ruthless Grunts) who make areas of the island uninhabitable.

I am a 38 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 9 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
